p.span: As a result of COVID-19 and the closing of schools, superintendents and charter school leaders must complete this packet and submit to the New Mexico Public Education Department by Wednesday, April 8, 2020.Â The packet contains the following items:

li.span: Assurances DocumentÂ
Continuous Learning PlanÂ
All required documents must be emailed as a single package to CL.Plan@state.nm.us by Wednesday, April 8, 2020.
Please direct questions to Gwen Perea Warniment, PhD, Deputy Secretary for Teaching, Learning, and Assessment at Gwen.Warniment@state.nm.us.

p.span: To access Continuous Learning guidance documents and resources, visit the PED website at:

div.h3: Continuous Learning Assurances Document & Local Plan

p.span: Welcome To The Home Of The Eagles!

Media Contact: David Morgan
Media and Social Media Manager, NMDOHÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
The New Mexico Department of Health announces drive-up screening for the COVID-19 coronavirus will be held Saturday, April 11
â by appointment only - at the Catron County Fairgrounds in Reserve, NM from 10 am â 1 pm.
To call for screening and a possible appointment for sample collection, contact 575-835-0971, extension 3. The screening is open to all residents meeting screening criteria, to include:
Symptomatic people displaying the COVID-19 symptoms of cough, fever or shortness of breath.
Asymptomatic people who are close contacts or household members of New Mexico residents who have already tested positive for the coronavirus;
Asymptomatic people in congregant settings such as homeless shelters, group homes, detention centers;
Residents with internet access can the Department of Healthâs online COVID-19 screening tool at
New Mexicans with health-related questions can call our coronavirus hotline at 855-600-3453. For non- health-related questions or concerns call 833-551-0518 or visit
, which is being updated and finalized as a one-stop source for information.
The state Department of Health also updates its dedicated COVID-19 webpage with additional information to include the latest COVID-19-related news, statewide screening and test sites and more at
Good morning Quemado School District parents/guardians/students/and community members,

The New Mexico Public Education Department, in coordination with the Governorâs Office, has announced a school closure for the remainder of this school year.Â Please see the following links for the official news release:

a.span: Frequently Asked Questions About Extended School ClosureÂ

p.span: Even though we will not be meeting in the traditional face-to-face school setting for the rest of this school year, our learning will continue.Â Teachers are hard at work planning for a transition to a distance learning model for the remainder of this school year.Â You can expect our transition process to look as follows:

li.span: March 25
:Â Teachers will reach out to families and students to reconnect and determine which students have access to devices with internet capability and consistent internet service.
March 30
â April 2

:Â Teachers will be planning for the transition to a distance learning model and training on new methods to communicate with students and their families.Â You can expect to see teachers beginning to organize communication methods and start to roll out guided learning activities.Â You can expect communication about how and when students can pick up their school issued computers (7
graders) and other personal items from the school.Â Â
Week of April 6

: Â Weekly learning packets (available on-line and/or hard copies) will be distributed.Â Where and when they can be picked up will be communicated to all students via all-calls, the school webpage, and the school Facebook page.Â Â

Following weeks:Â Our staff will work to scale up the distance learning model.Â We do not expect everything we try to work the first time.Â We will take what works well and grow it while adjusting or disposing of what does not work well.Â This will be learning process for everyone involved.

p.span: What the Distance Learning Model will be:

li.span: A time for students to learn and grow with engaging and challenging activities provided by teachers and guided by a partnership between parents and teachers.
A time for students to connect with teachers and classmates.
An opportunity for parents to be deeply involved in the learning process
A mixture of online activities and learning packets provided weekly by teachers.
A focus on fundamental academic skills required to move on to the next level.
Academic activities the whole family can participate in.
A time for teachers, students, and families to connect.
Respectful of work and family responsibilities parents have.

p.span: The Distance Learning Model will NOT be a traditional school day.Â The time expected for students to be engaged will be as follows:

li.span: Pre-K â maximum of 30 minutes a day
Grades K-1 â maximum of 45 minutes per day
Grades 2-3 â maximum of 60 minutes per day
Grades 4-5 â maximum of 90 minutes per day
Grades 6-12 â 30 minutes per teacher with a maximum of 3 hours per day

p.span: There have been a lot of questions concerning special events like prom and graduation.Â The bottom line is we will follow the Public Health Order guidelines issued by the governor.Â Special events may be possible if the health order is lifted.Â If not, we will postpone the events until a later date.Â Only as a last resort will we even consider cancelling the events as our students have worked hard and deserve the recognition.

Although pandemics are nothing new when you study history, this is definitely a first for all of us in our educational careers.Â Our commitment is to work together with our community to provide learning opportunities for our students in this unprecedented time.Â Together we will focus on the opportunities this event presents us with: new and stronger relationships between teachers and the families we serve, new approaches to how learning is accomplished, and coming together as a community to get through a difficult time, just to name a few.

Please be on the lookout for information over the next week.Â Teachers will be seeking information and input from families in order to create a plan that works.Â As the plan is developed they will be sharing information out.
If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me directly.
Â Â Â Â Â A

li.span: Finances:Â Long-term plans, better information systems
Personnel:Â Seek, retain and support highly qualified staff
Develop strategies and implement programs to assist in fostering parent and community involvement.
Focus on core curriculum to include health and physical education programs K-12.
Implementation of strategies and programs to assist students who are not meeting standards and benchmarks.
